column1: mr-ore 160356667909 "2017-05-06 03:39:58 GMT" https://mr-ore.tumblr.com/post/160356667909/china-creates-artificial-star-8600-times-hotter "canonicalmomentum: superluminalflower:  justsomeantifas: The world of renewable energy more powerful than any fossil fuel combined is near. christ on a bike  Tokamaks are amazing things
column2: but the hype is a bit much here. Fusion power is not by any means near. The comparison with a star is a bit misleading - both stars and tokamaks produce energy by nuclear fusion
column3: but where stars are a dense cloud of hot gas held permanently together by gravity
column4: tokamaks are a very thin plasma whirling around the core of a torus that dissipates as soon as the magnetic field collapses or the temperature drops. While the temperatures at the core of a tokamak sound astonishing
column6: the actual amount of material held at this temperature is very small so the amount of energy in the plasma is not as large as youâ€™d think. This article doesnâ€™t discuss whether the EAST was able to produce more energy through fusion than was used to heat the plasma (not to mention the energy used to maintain the superconducting magnet coils). But if it had been able to do that
column7: this would have been much bigger news. This is a very impressive technical achievement
column8: but it doesnâ€™t mean fusion is right around the corner. The running joke is that fusion energy is â€œalways 30 years awayâ€ but indeed itâ€™s already looking like more. Experimental fusion tokamaks have been operational for decades now. The ones I know most about are JET and MAST
column9: which I got the chance to visit a few years ago - but weâ€™re still a long way from generating net energy by fusion. That means that although nuclear fusion takes place in the tokamak
column10: the energy produced by fusion is not enough toÂ â€˜break evenâ€™ and keep the plasma hot enough for fusion to keep going. â€˜Breaking evenâ€™ is the objective of ITER
column11: the enormous still-under-construction international collaboration to construct a tokamak that can generate more power than is put into it. (EAST from outside - source) So
column13: EAST is a research project helping scientists and engineers understand the physics involved in building ITER and future fusion reactors
column14: not a model for an electrical generator. While JET uses copper conductors to generate its containing magnetic field
column15: EAST uses superconductors (ITER is also intended to use superconductors) - hence its name
column16: the Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak.  Superconductors - which have effectively no electrical resistance when  theyâ€™re kept below a certain temperature - have the advantage of  drastically reducing losses to heat from the enormous currents flowing  through the conductors and therefore allowing higher currents to be used  and stronger magnetic fields to be produced
column17: but introduce the new  problem of keeping a superconductor at liquid nitrogen temperatures a  relatively tiny distance from a superheated plasma at a temperature of  millions of Kelvin (degrees C). One of the major objectives of EAST is  to test superconductor confinement of the kind intended to be used in  ITER.   EAST is a large tokamak but not the largest currently in operation
column18: comparable to a number of experimental tokamaks in various countries. The above 2016 experiment is not the longest plasma pulse in a tokamak - that record is about 400s
column19: currently held by the French tokamak Tore Supra
column21: and had a bit of a head start having been built in 1988. However
column22: EAST is intended to create plasma pulses of up to 1000s
column23: so maybe theyâ€™ll break that record. So this research is all very exciting. But fusion power stations are not just around the corner. Assuming the construction of ITER goes as planned
column24: it will not begin plasma experiments until 2020
column25: and fusion until 2027. But itâ€™s already been delayed
column26: and may well be delayed further. (the ITER building site - source) Once ITER is built successfully
column27: itâ€™s not a power station. It will take longer still for a demonstration fusion power station with the required parameters to be built. Termed DEMO
column28: such a demonstration system was originally intended to begin fusion experiments in 2033
column29: then this was pushed back to 2044 with power generation in 2047. A subsequent two â€˜roadmapsâ€™ were not written because the organisation responsible was â€˜supersededâ€™ by a different organisation
column30: so itâ€™s probably been delayed further. At least
column31: its final design (let alone construction) is waiting on data from ITER. Once DEMO is built
column32: though it will generate a fair chunk of energy
column33: itâ€™s still not the prototype for a first commercial power station. Thatâ€™s nicknamed PROTO
column34: and its design is even hazier. Even once a prototype power station is built and tested
column35: the project of replacing a significant portion of the worldâ€™s power generation with fusion would take a long
column37: long time. Long enough that itâ€™s certainly not going to be much use as a climate change mitigation strategy. In the long term
column39: fusion energy could be great. Fusion energy isnâ€™t as messy as fission energy
column40: nor as likely to cause a catastrophic accident (since if containment fails
column42: heating up the walls of the reactor but not producing loads of radioactive waste the way a fission plant does). But it does produce radioactive waste
column43: since the plasma-facing surfaces of the reactor become irradiated. (Part of the fusion research programme is to identify plasma-facing materials whose activation products have a short half-life
column44: so their radioactivity will be short-lived. Thereâ€™s a plan to create a facility called the IMFIF to research this
column45: and DEMO is supposed to use data from its research
column48: calling fusion energy renewable is strictly speaking incorrect - it relies on deuterium and tritium (isotopes of hydrogen). Deuterium can be produced from seawater
column49: while tritium is planned to be produced using lithium in the reactor itself. ITERâ€™s site claims that worldwide reserves of lithium would allow the use of reactors for â€œmore than 1
column50: 000 yearsâ€ from land and â€œmillions of yearsâ€ from sea
column51: but I donâ€™t know what assumptions go into that calculation. It is of course still a much longer-lasting supply than fossil fuels or fission. However
column52: saying itâ€™s totally greenhouse gas free is not true. Just like fission power plants
column53: constructing fusion plants will require setting large amounts of concrete (though maybe not as much since the needs of radioactive containment are different). Iâ€™m not sure what the estimated lifetime emissions of a fusion plant are
column54: but they wonâ€™t be nothing. Still
column55: they should be better than fossil fuels
column56: and probably will be better than fission energy. Iâ€™m also not sure how quickly lithium will need to be mined as the tritium source. Thatâ€™s all very far in the future though - most likely most of us will not live to see a future of fusion power
column57: and climate change is sufficiently urgent that we canâ€™t afford to wait for fusion power to be invented before we drastically cut down fossil fuel production. Other renewables have different limitations - very high land use
column59: and managing fluctuating power on the grid - but they can deployed much sooner. But that will
column61: not happen on the scale needed under capitalism. " False link

column1: mr-ore 160171049991 "2017-05-01 00:09:45 GMT" https://mr-ore.tumblr.com/post/160171049991/desperate-families-driven-to-black-market-insulin "alexaweinstein:  berniesrevolution:  Fourth grader Gabriella Corley is trapped. She has type-1 diabetes and is allergic to the kind of insulin her insurer makes affordable â€” and her family canâ€™t pay for the kind she needs every day to stay alive. Glancing at the cheerleader from Elkins
column2: West Virginia
column4: held up on her teammatesâ€™ shoulders
column5: her grin as wide as her two fists in the air
column6: you might not think anything was wrong. Then you might notice the insulin pump about the size of a pager tucked into her black compression shorts
column7: clear tubes going under her shirt. It infuses insulin directly into her body through a tube connected to a site on her abdomen. â€œSheâ€™s a beautiful
column9: amazing little 10-year-old girl who stands up in the face of adversity every single day without blinking an eye and does it with a smile
column11: 32-year-old Andrea Corley. Soaring insulin prices and inflexible insurance policies have forced this working-class mom to take desperate measures outside the system to keep her child alive. Gabriella is allergic to the kind of insulin her insurer covers at a $25 out-of-pocket cost. She can only take Apidra
column12: but her insurance only covers 25 percent of the price
column13: leaving the family to pay hundreds of dollars a month they canâ€™t afford. So her mom has turned to the black market
column14: trading for the medication with other families with diabetes she meets online
column15: a tactic that regulators and health experts warn is a health risk. And she cut a back-end deal with a sympathetic drug rep: If she bought one vial he would give her 10 vials from his sample kit

UPDATE 4/10/17 Chechnya has opened concentration camps for gay men   Gay men arrested in a â€˜purgeâ€™ in the Russian region of Chechnya are being held in concentration camp-style prisons
column22: reports have alleged. Early reports emerged earlier this month that gay people are being targeted in the region
column23: which is part of Russia but has substantial autonomy. Russian newspapers and human rights groups report that more than 100 gay men have been detained â€œin connection with their non-traditional sexual orientation
column24: or suspicion of suchâ€ as part of a purge. Several people were also reportedly feared dead following violent raids. In a chilling response

column26: insisting that â€œyou canâ€™t detain and harass someone who doesnâ€™t exist in the republicâ€. The Kremlin denied any knowledge of a purge. But reports have since emerged that the men arrested are being kept in horrific concentration camp prisons
column27: where violent abuse and torture is common. Based on interviews with eyewitnesses and survivors
